32D12449AC874327ABA4FF3FD128D05A.description: Examine the Human Genome Project (HGP) as an example of a collaborative scientific endeavour

8EB59D7E00D84BC2811535ADB0B26BAA.description: Defend a position related to intellectual property rights in biotechnology such as genome ownership and whether patents should include owning the rights to organisms or parts of organisms.

15EAA8178F4D4E0EB7F68F001628F627.description: Analyze the role of regulation and legislation in providing a level of public safety pertaining to applications of biotechnology.

86CB3C365C1C45588A9F8F5E3F4D74F1.description: Critique the media’s role in crafting public perception related to biotechnologies (e.g., vaccines, genetically modified organisms and genetic screening).

935B001F14184CDCB15BEDC4782C10F7.description: Critique how individuals and groups use and misuse scientific information to support their positions regarding biotechnologies such as vaccines

D0D0ED0F08324F5E95670B762D4E081C.description: Explore how the use and misuse of antibiotics has led to increased bacterial resistance, including the emergence of superbugs.

999C0B022F194979BE521F38F2E43D17.description: Explore potential positive and negative impacts of a specific biotechnology (e.g., the use of stem cells, genetically modified and synthetic organisms and synthetic DNA) on individuals and society.

9B4FAC3F948A45179BF33E401FFA1A0F.description: Research a medical (e.g., 3-D bio printing, personalized medicine, genetic testing and screening and gene therapy) or industrial (e.g., use of recombinant DNA, biofuels and bioremediation) application of biotechnology.

AEF28C3FB107438DBEA4D1C9EF60DF41.description: Explore how societal pressures such as food, energy and resource shortages can drive the development of biotechnologies.

3E00F0F3320A43C1987F5701FCEEAD54.description: Identify examples of historical, current and emerging biotechnologies (e.g., selective breeding, applications of fermentation, genetic engineering, cloning, gene therapy, assistive reproductive technologies and synthetic biology).

3995E6C2E41F4EAAB19490FEC39E85B0.description: Explore the impacts of historical, current and emerging biotechnologies on self, society and the environment.

9C8EB2E5A11A4897B611C3D21F28B6F7.description: Model or simulate common techniques (e.g., agarose gel electrophoresis, polymerase chain reaction, DNA sequencing and DNA fingerprinting) used by molecular geneticists.

B870A8C01DBC4CE8BD6877DD45F8C308.description: Describe how environmental and epigenetic factors influence genetic expression.

54558DE212974FDAA36C7517CCF4DE83.description: Assess the role of genetic mutation in the process of evolution.

96F075A1A32546B899C84F55C1073E66.description: Recognize how various types of gene mutations (e.g., deletion, insertion, point and frameshift) may lead to genetic disorders. (K) f. Discuss the value of DNA proofreading and repair and its role in preventing genetic mutations.

B07AF38CFC194A8883C3E426459394C5.description: Model molecular genetic processes of DNA replication and protein synthesis (i.e., transcription and translation), including the roles of DNA, mRNA, tRNA and rRNA.

FB369EE30BC34020A123B2BC2FBDEDBE.description: Assess the importance of the structure of the DNA molecule to its ability to store, transmit and express genetic information.

E4FF4D1F1A764C53B2A990462FAC7165.description: Research the nature of the predominant scientific culture when scientists such as Erwin Chargaff, Rosalind Franklin, Maurice Wilkins, James Watson and Francis Crick were investigating the chemical basis of inheritance.

52DFB80088884793AB13AE2FEFBA2F70.description: Appreciate how the discovery of the DNA molecule as the chemical basis of inheritance has fundamentally transformed the field of biology.

FEC744DF716C44A09C9F318A77645F57.description: Investigate how genetic information is stored, transmitted and expressed at the molecular level.

53A3BB49B5F344D2B9E03E90FF6CFA0F.description: Identify, using karyotypes, chromosomal abnormalities and how these abnormalities may lead to chromosomal disorders such as Klinefelter syndrome, Down syndrome and Turner syndrome.

C0F0324F96064CF9A5159168D7FC96FD.description: Investigate the importance of meiosis, including crossing-over, in creating genetic variation in gametes and non-disjunction in creating chromosomal abnormalities.

6A6A5B3825154543959E533BC51ED9A0.description: Recognize that scientists now understand chromosomes to be the mechanism of Mendel’s laws (i.e., law of segregation, law of independent assortment and law of dominance).

40B923BE403B4E059D6D37FD5F0CBFA1.description: Describe how gene flow, genetic drift and natural selection influence the frequency of alleles within a population.

BE9BAEBDE7A94F9C92A042B2D85B237A.description: Construct Punnett squares for monohybrid crosses using P1 genotypes (i.e., homozygous and heterozygous) to determine genotypic and phenotypic frequencies for F1 and F2 generations.

B386ABC5AC8E4163ACD549198911A182.description: Determine an organism’s phenotype from its genotype, and where possible, its genotype from its phenotype.

3C5555D992C74F82BC61107380F495F4.description: Distinguish among patterns of inheritance (e.g., dominant and recessive alleles, sex-linked traits, codominance, incomplete dominance, multiple alleles and polygenic inheritance) of heritable traits.

587DAD1B355A4B7AB25E7F0AF58B2499.description: Discuss the importance of probability in predicting the likelihood of inheriting particular traits.

561F5C1B8A844850B165A589CDB6863F.description: Discuss the historical development of Mendelian genetics, including why Gregor Mendel is considered the “father of genetics”.

CD16DCCDE2D04D64A8D5EBDCC7C1E230.description: Explore patterns of inheritance by interpreting pedigrees, including your own family tree.

81CFA43FABC3488999D79F5B834E6112.description: Pose questions about why and how offspring only inherit some traits from their parents.

CB27E50E9D754348B87F58B9A4653DA9.description: Explore classical (i.e. Mendelian) and current (i.e. chromosomal) understandings of biological inheritance.

7B4B90F76DDE424A8E38805BEF2D0DD7.description: Develop generalizations about the value of biological classification systems.

D08C1CAD25994C238C7FCD927DF792BC.description: Critique the strengths and limitations of historical and contemporary systems of classifying living things.

F5E73093BEB84301BAD8E19BC2EADB56.description: Demonstrate, using cladograms, how phylogenetic relationships inform our contemporary understanding of biological classification.

16811562FBBB4E9B94096955457AB08E.description: Create and use dichotomous keys to gain insights into the challenges of biological classification.

1C1C96560869406A9425B7796F97FEC8.description: Discuss the challenges associated with classification, including defining taxa and classifying certain organisms, such as protists.

D543EF5E8F584F5686B3439D78C9B02D.description: Discuss how the characteristics of the taxonomic hierarchy represent relationships among organisms.

47EA32F159344B428DDA3D52F80A05B7.description: Research the contributions of scientists, including Carl Linnaeus, in developing accepted scientific conventions for the naming of organisms.

8D1DA17DFA204435AA7B7182965FFF69.description: Research how First Nations, Métis and Inuit peoples represent their understandings of relationships among living things

8CA3900D84B445A18560B9BC0B6052F4.description: Discuss how classification systems are designed by humans to meet various needs.

5EAC96D817C34D67B34FBBFB266944C5.description: Explore how the dynamic nature of biological classification reflects advances in scientific understanding of relationships among organisms.

BA2151D0A9DE4991B55E49DDF3E68077.description: Compare how multicellular organisms acquire, transport and excrete materials (e.g., nutrients, hormones and wastes) intraorganismally and interorganismally, including through symbiotic relationships (e.g., mutualism, commensalism, and parasitism).

26CD4EE601D940BC813446C24B1E8CE4.description: Identify how multicellular organisms maintain homeostasis through processes such as biofeedback, fluid regulation and thermoregulation.

C6F367DBC6A145D4923C3C579F7F73EA.description: Design and carry out an experiment to determine how multicellular organisms respond to various stimuli (e.g., light, touch, gravity, pheromones and other chemicals).

328AF4729FCE4D8481CE3D1652AB903E.description: Explore the behavioural, structural and physiological adaptations that enable organisms to defend themselves against threats, such as pathogens, predators and disease.

2AA71A0259824E66B8AEC8926525F692.description: Analyze the evolutionary costs and benefits of various reproductive strategies evident among multicellular organisms.

2A98EA0A207547EF9DC5AD7B2BB410EA.description: Research First Nations and Métis perspectives regarding the use of living things for scientific research.

39BB30FE732D4A489615DE63A2FA8546.description: Discuss the ethical implications of using model organisms (e.g., Aspergillus nidulans, slime moulds, C. elegans, Arabidopsis, Drosophila and mice) and humans to further scientific understandings of anatomy and physiology.

659B7BCB47A9406BA1109C8EE64F9CAC.description: Compare the anatomical structures and functions of organisms using microscopy, simulations and/or dissections where appropriate.

476FA96949234E15B131D49C2D9D70E6.description: Compare the anatomies, physiologies and behaviours of multicellular organisms including protists, fungi, plants and animals.

3B6F10D72EC647A79F2CE56EFB135BBF.description: Demonstrate how osmotic pressure helps maintain homeostasis in cells.

CDEC6D2F43644011B0F2A6370A734786.description: Design, construct and evaluate the function of a model to demonstrate passive and active transport of materials at the interface of the cell membrane.

37B5D04215764754A96122D5BD6F3F45.description: Research how advances in tools (e.g., light microscopes, transmission electron microscopes and scanning electron microscopes) and techniques (e.g., culturing cells and cell fractionation) have enabled scientists to develop deeper understandings of cell structure and processes.

84F06CB575AB4C05AA8ABF2CD291189A.description: Observe and compare structures (e.g., pseudopods, cilia and flagella) and processes that enable locomotion in unicellular organisms such as amoeba, paramecium, dinoflagellates and euglena.

E5D33B1FDFCF4606B3C05BBD3F3DBBD1.description: Research how structural and biochemical adaptations enable some archaeans (e.g., halophiles, thermophiles and methanogens) to live in extreme environments.

D14FD9653ED24B5B9B7F3A1CA5FECBF2.description: Design and carry out a plan to gather evidence of how unicellular organisms, such as yeast or paramecia, exhibit characteristics of living things

B5659BD9F5054376B21EAF5711207EF5.description: Compare the structure and composition (e.g., chitin, cellulose and peptidoglycan) of cell walls in a variety of organisms.

BA44EC8C281E4B588ECCB9AFBCC09DB5.description: Describe how biologically important molecules work together to form complex structures (e.g., cell membranes, ribosomes and deoxyribonucleic acid [DNA]).

94A0EF555F0B4303A1DD53A09700FCB8.description: Analyze the processes (e.g., chemosynthesis, photosynthesis and cellular respiration) through which organisms from each kingdom synthesize energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate.

7C1D1FF446FD438DBB53A48715068C74.description: Pose questions regarding the diverse ways in which organisms perform life’s processes such as locomotion, reproduction, acquiring energy and responding to stimuli.

8F3DB293112745DAA0E52E605E9659B0.description: Investigate cell structure and processes, including energy transfer and transport of materials, in unicellular and multicellular organisms which are representative of each kingdom.

818A9F2FF2E2487387CF6D222895C4AA.description: Explore human evolution in relationship to other primates, considering the Out of Africa hypothesis and the agricultural revolution.

7D2464411A004323831BC6B813F9DE9B.description: Examine how scientists use the fossil record, radioactive dating, comparative embryology and homologous and analogous structures as evidence of biological evolution.

45DD9CDD36894066A5BA3D1198583DC8.description: Identify concepts (e.g., gradualism versus punctuated equilibrium, convergent evolution, divergent evolution, coevolution, adaptive radiation, mass-extinction and the evolutionary arms race) that are only evident when examining evolution over a multitude of generations extending to geological time

D824FB73FFA0496AA09E179B3ECBEB0C.description: Explain how geographic, temporal and behavioural isolation can influence speciation.

3078598D225D470EB015941744DD2485.description: Examine how particular selective pressures (e.g., competition, predation, changes in climate, parasitism and pollution) acting on an individual can influence a population over time. (

2E6B817B6CB9450DB459B0E88A4F8FB1.description: Recognize how the principles of natural selection occur at the level of the individual and may result in the evolution of the population.

3293C928B1B14C17B78583CBC26131DD.description: Discuss how Darwin’s observations informed the development of the theory of natural selection as a mechanism of evolution.

0D2EDA9E98D84FA0955B7456EE2AEC5B.description: Identify historical perspectives and key contributions to the field of evolutionary biology by scientists such as Jean-Baptiste Lamarck, Thomas Robert Malthus, Charles Darwin, Alfred Russel Wallace, Alfred Wegener, Theodosius Dobzhansky, Lynn Margulis, Stephen Jay Gould, and E. O. Wilson. (K, STSE)

F3FC52D7352146B4955D668D62E56723.description: Interpret cladograms and phylogenetic trees to determine evolutionary relationships among organisms.

46A62936EBBE46C28558C4633C596476.description: Explain the importance of the concept of the last universal common ancestor (LUCA) in understanding evolutionary relationships among organisms.

D1647A30F2634CA4BA87D1FB2BBD0F65.description: Investigate how humans use selective breeding (i.e., artificial selection) to enhance desirable characteristics in organisms.

D3BCC7D7350D44AB93D6093D0C7E95DC.description: Outline the key principles (e.g., descent with modification, fitness as a result of adaptations and struggle for existence) and processes (e.g., natural selection, genetic drift and selective breeding) of biological evolution.

6E33099DA9404A66A273C6B78566BA87.description: Identify common misconceptions (e.g., individuals evolve, natural selection is evolution, evolution is random and evolution is a theory) regarding biological evolution.

0BDFB04B256142B6B41DA52BE54A85D3.description: Examine the significance of evolution as a key unifying theme in biology through the principles, processes and patterns of biological evolution.

31783486DBD94503B41E87216423FEC2.description: Create a representation of historical events related to the study of life.

7A0A7EC921E24AE7A30F088A85CD87E8.description: Examine the impact of the cell theory and advances in microscopy on past and current scientific definitions of life.

14B69C1B106C4FF584FBDE5B86BB06BD.description: Recognize the contribution of scientists (e.g., Francesco Redi, Louis Pasteur, Stanley Miller, Harold Urey and Lynn Margulis) whose experiments contributed to a wider understanding of life from a biological perspective

40DAF37CD4DF4C1DA4DB42316CF762CF.description: Debate whether or not entities such as viruses, viroids and prions should be considered alive.

76D9C5BAF8CD40EDBE0502C97301C061.description: Explore how scientific definitions of life have changed over time as a result of advances in technologies and scientific understanding.

97270CB8352D4CD0AAE35C10B4E97DEC.description: Distinguish among scientific, First Nations, Métis, Inuit and other cultural perspectives with respect to the question of what constitutes life.

BAAF0CC3CC454544994B0DA0FE937A56.description: Explain what characteristics you use to define what is or what is not considered living.

2F1DD1D690D3478FADADDBE64B32816E.description: Explore how scientific understandings of life and its characteristics change in light of new evidence.

1622B2927C9C4753A60547854AF89319.description: Construct a tool (e.g., rubric, checklist, self-evaluation form or peer-evaluation form) to assess the process and products involved in a student-directed study.

F0FCA9B86A2949C2B41B9C58DFF28CB7.description: Share the results of student-directed research through a display, presentation, performance, demonstration, song, game, commercial, fine art representation, video or research paper

EB7C5012F2064892912865E7F7A6F7BC.description: Debate an issued related to biology, including developing  materials to support the arguments for and arguments against a position.

AB0857863B70416E8018B0A84FEBEA11.description: Design, construct and evaluate the effectiveness of a device, model or technique that demonstrates the scientific principles underlying concept related to a Biology 30 topic.

E0690080E8F140B1A82285BB5766D830.description: Assemble and reflect on a portfolio that demonstrates an understanding of a topic of interest related to biology

A6CB0F1EE0534F65810945CBD4CDD270.description: Carry out an experiment following established scientific protocols to investigate a question of interest related to one or more of the topics of Biology 30.

BFBF7F88E87B4509902CD77680CC8E67.description: Design a scientific investigation related to a topic of study in Biology 30 that includes a testable question, a hypothesis, an experimental design that will test the hypothesis and detailed procedures for collecting and analyzing data.

D567721A238645FFBA586643AFC2C58B.description: Create and carry out a plan to explore one or more topics of personal interest relevant to Biology 30 in depth.
